2014 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: June 11, 2014  Wetland muskeg appears to have been ramped on work side of ROW. There is no mulch present.  Regeneration of native plant and tree species is excellent on work side. Moss is also recovering very well.  Vegetation on ramped portion (work side) of ROW differs from spoil side. The different access methods (freeze down and ramping) are very evident through wetland portion. Ramping seems to have been very effective.  Vegetation looks good on spoil side but natives don’t seem to be as successful on spoil side of ROW.  Minor rutting in wetland portion likely from recreational quad use.

Willows and deciduous species starting to advance in wetland throughout ROW. Exceptional growth of Sphagnum moss throughout wetland. Good depth of organic substrate in wetland indicates proper wetland functionality and stability. Up to 15 cm of standing water present in bog at time of assessment, may be attributed to recent precipitation event. No sedimentation issues apparent in bog. No subsidence or erosion issues present in wetland. Abundance of amphibians using wetland as suitable habitat. No net loss of wetland function evident at time of assessment.

2013 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: KP 36+800 Removed all steel pegs and non-biodegradable material from seasonal drain. Redistributed the cobble that is holding back water. Checked for depth of cover with hand probe before any shovel work to correct drainage and cobble being redistributed.
2014 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: June 20, 2014  Tributary to Cutbank River W16 at 11U 6052559m N, 0374023m E (KP 36+800) shows good vegetation proliferation along both banks with slightly greater establishment on north bank. Minor subsidence evident on north bank, 4m X 5 m X 20–30 cm in magnitude. Minor subsidence evident on south bank, 4 m X 4 m X 30–40 cm in magnitude. Minor slumping evident on ditchline indicated by greater ponding of water. Minimal flow in tributary at time of assessment.

June 20, 2014  90–95% vegetation cover on ROW compared with off-ROW control. Good establishment of willow, deciduous species along ROW.  Tall buttercup found in tract. Solitary weeds were hand-picked and bagged. June 26, 2014  Approximately 1.5 ha was sprayed between KP 36+900 and 37+700 with herbicide to control tall buttercup and scentless chamomile. July 23, 2014  Previously sprayed herbicide applied intermittently throughout this tract appears successful. Broadleaf species in areas sprayed showing signs of health degradation in the form of wilting and discolouration. Grasses mainly unaffected.

2013 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: KP 37+200 Minor subsidence (11U 0374028, 6052205) – monitor in 2014 to determine if repairs are required. KP 37+200 Removed all steel pegs and non-biodegradable material from seasonal drain. Redistributed the cobble that is holding back water. Checked for depth of cover with hand probe before any shovel work to correct drainage and cobble being redistributed.
2014 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: June 20, 2014  Tributary to Cutbank River W17 at 11U m N, m E (KP 37+200) shows 80–85% vegetation cover on north bank and 75–80% vegetation cover on south bank with good willow and deciduous species’ proliferating. No subsidence or erosion issues in tributary. Moderate water flow in tributary at time of assessment. Amphibians using tributary as habitat. June 26, 2014  Tall buttercup present from kp 37+170 to kp 37+280 in extensive amount in 30m buffer of watercourse crossing and rare plant area. The watercourses involved include Tributary to Cutbank River WC 17 and Tributary to Cutbank River WC 18. Requires mechanical removal. July 4, 2014  Picked and bagged 30 m X 30 m section of high density noxious weed (buttercup) in 30 m of watercourse.

2013 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: KP 37+300 Removed all steel pegs and non-biodegradable material from seasonal drain. Redistributed the cobble that is holding back water. Checked for depth of cover with hand probe before any shovel work to correct drainage and cobble being redistributed.
2014 PCRM Assessment and Work Completed: June 20, 2014  Tributary to Cutbank River W18 at 11U m N, m E (KP 37+300) exhibits 90% vegetation cover on north bank and 80–85% vegetation cover on south bank with good willow and deciduous species’ proliferating. Minor subsidence evident on north bank, 5 m X 5 m X 10 cm in magnitude. Moderate water flow in tributary at time of assessment. Amphibians using tributary as habitat. June 26, 2014  Tall buttercup present from KP 37+170 to KP 37+280 in extensive amount in 30 m buffer of watercourse crossing and rare plant area. The watercourses involved include tributary to Cutbank River WC 17 and tributary to Cutbank River WC 18. Requires mechanical removal. July 4, 2014  Picked and bagged 30 m X 30 m section of high-density noxious weed (buttercup) in 30 m of watercourse.

June 20, 2014  95% vegetation establishment as opposed to off-ROW. Good establishment of native grasses across ROW. Deciduous species establishing. Cross drains functioning effectively with vegetation establishing. Some water present.  Tall buttercup and scentless chamomile located on ROW. June 26, 2014  Approximately 0.16 ha was sprayed between KP 37+700 and 37+900 with herbicide to control Tall Buttercup and scentless chamomile. July 23, 2014  Previously sprayed herbicide applied intermittently throughout this tract appears successful. Broadleaf species in areas sprayed showing signs of health degradation in the form of wilting and discolouration. Grasses mainly unaffected.  Scentless chamomile identified in extra workspace at KP 37+900 adjacent the valve station. Area identified was not previously sprayed. Spraying is recommended. July 28, 2014  Scentless chamomile was handpicked and bagged for disposal at KP 37+900. Approximately 0.25 large garbage bags were picked from location.  Approximately 0.16 ha was sprayed to control scentless chamomile. September 19, 2014  Approximately 0.02 ha was sprayed to control areas of Canada thistle. 
